docs.title: ❤️‍🩹 Social Media Downloader
docs.text:
Welcome to the official documentation for Social Media Downloader — a fast, simple, and open-source command-line tool for downloading public videos from your favorite platforms including YouTube, TikTok, Facebook, Instagram, and many more.

Start Here

This documentation is your guide to getting started, troubleshooting issues, exploring features, and contributing to the project.

docs.title: Why Use Social Media Downloader?
docs.text:
In today’s digital world, media moves fast — and so do you. Whether you're a developer, content creator, researcher, or just someone who wants a quick way to save videos offline, Social Media Downloader is designed to do one thing exceptionally well: Download public media reliably and efficiently from a wide range of platforms.

Why Thousands Trust It

  • Available as .exe, .deb, pip and Linux binary
  • Built with ❤️ using Python — lightweight and powerful
  • 100% free and open-source
  • Works on Windows & Linux
  • No bloated GUIs — pure CLI simplicity

docs.title: What You Get
docs.text:
When you install Social Media Downloader, you gain:

  • A clean and powerful command-line interface (CLI)
  • Automatic format detection and download options
  • Lightweight performance with no third-party junk
  • Easy integration into your own scripts or tools

Tip

If you're automating workflows or building scraping utilities, SMD fits right in with your shell scripts or Python pipelines.

docs.title: Supported Platforms
docs.text:
We currently support public video links from:

  • YouTube
  • TikTok
  • Instagram
  • Facebook
  • X (formerly Twitter)
  • And more... View the full list of supported platforms.

Constantly Evolving

We’re actively adding support for more platforms. Have a request? Open an issue or submit a pull request!

For Developers

Our modular architecture makes it easy to add new platform handlers. Come contribute — it’s simpler than you think!

docs.title: 🫗 Build Instructions
docs.text: Want to turn Social Media Downloader into a standalone executable? Whether you're building for Windows or Linux, this guide will walk you through everything you need using PyInstaller.

docs.title: Install PyInstaller
docs.text:
First, make sure you have PyInstaller installed. It converts your Python scripts into standalone executables for easy distribution — no Python installation required on the end user’s system.

pip3 install pyinstaller

docs.title: Building on Windows
docs.text: You’ve got a few options depending on how you want your executable to behave:

docs.title: Console Version
docs.text:
This version will open a terminal/console window when run.

pyinstaller --onefile smd/downloader.py

docs.title: Silent Version (No Console Window)
docs.text:
If you want to hide the terminal window (for example, when launching from a desktop shortcut or GUI), use:

pyinstaller --onefile --noconsole smd/downloader.py

docs.title: With a Custom Icon
docs.text:
Want a polished feel? Add your own .ico file to give the executable a custom icon:

pyinstaller --onefile --icon=assets/logo.ico smd/downloader.py

Important

Make sure your icon file is in .ico format. If you’re using .png, you can convert it using an online tool or image editor.

After the build completes, your .exe file will be located in the dist/ folder.

docs.title: Building on Linux
docs.text:
Building on Linux is just as straightforward. Run:

pyinstaller --onefile smd/downloader.py

Once the build finishes, make the output binary executable:

chmod +x dist/downloader
./dist/downloader

You now have a portable binary that can run on any compatible Linux system.

docs.title: Font Issues?
docs.text:
Tip

If you're seeing missing fonts or broken ASCII art from pyfiglet, head over to the Troubleshooting page for help resolving that.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
By default, PyInstaller creates two folders:

  • dist/ — contains your final executable
  • build/ — temporary build files (you can usually delete this after packaging)

Your single-file executable will always be located in the dist/ directory.

docs.title: Clean Up (Optional)
docs.text:
Want to clean the extra files after a build?

rm -rf build __pycache__ *.spec

This will leave you with just your source code and the dist/ folder containing your binary.

You're now ready to distribute your own standalone version of Social Media Downloader!

Tip

Need .deb or other platform-specific packages? Stay tuned for packaging instructions in the future or check out our Release Archive.

docs.title: Configuration File: config.json
docs.text:
When you launch Social Media Downloader for the first time, a configuration file named config.json is automatically generated. This file stores your personal settings and download preferences locally.

Note

The config.json file is created in the same directory where you run the tool. We recommend launching the CLI from your Desktop or a clean folder for better file organization.

docs.title: Default Configuration
docs.text:
Here is the default content of the config.json file:

{
  "default_format": "show_all",
  "download_directory": "media",
  "history_file": "download_history.csv",
  "mp3_quality": "192"
}

docs.title: Configuration Keys Explained
docs.text: Key Description default_format The preferred format for downloads. Choose mp3, a video quality like 720p, or show_all download_directory The folder where downloaded files are saved (default: media/) history_file CSV file used to keep track of download history mp3_quality MP3 bitrate quality in kbps (e.g. 192, 320, etc.)

docs.title: Video Quality Options (default_format)
docs.text:
You can set the default_format to a specific video resolution to automatically download the best available video at or below that quality:

  • "360p" – Mobile-friendly, small file size
  • "480p" – Standard definition (SD)
  • "720p" – High definition (HD)
  • "1080p" – Full HD (recommended for good balance)
  • "1440p" – Quad HD (2K)
  • "2160p" – Ultra HD (4K)
  • "4320p" – 8K (rarely used, very large files)

Or set to:

  • "mp3" – For audio-only downloads
  • "show_all" – Prompts you to select a format manually for each download

docs.title: MP3 Quality Options
docs.text:
When default_format is set to "mp3", the tool uses ffmpeg to extract audio from videos. The mp3_quality setting determines the bitrate:

Value Quality 64 Low 128 Medium 192 Default / Balanced 256 High 320 Very High 396 Maximum (rarely used)

Tip

Higher bitrates mean better audio quality — but also larger file sizes.

docs.title: Smart Config Handling (v1.1.8+)
docs.text:
Starting from version 1.1.8, there's no need to manually delete the config.json file if a setting is missing or invalid.

✅ The tool automatically detects and resets incorrect or missing values to safe defaults during startup.

docs.title: Manual Editing
docs.text: You can open config.json in any text editor like Notepad, VS Code, or Sublime Text to make changes.

docs.title: Example: Auto-download MP3s to your Downloads folder
docs.text:
{
  "default_format": "mp3",
  "download_directory": "C:/Users/YourName/Downloads",
  "history_file": "download_history.csv",
  "mp3_quality": "320"
}

Warning

Make sure the folder you specify for download_directory already exists. The tool won’t create nested directories.

docs.title: For Users on v1.0.0 – v1.1.7
docs.text:
Older versions do not automatically fix or regenerate the config file. If you experience errors or missing settings:

🚫 Delete your config.json manually ✅ Relaunch the tool — it will create a fresh file with correct defaults.

docs.title: Other Auto-Created Files
docs.text: File Name Purpose config.json Stores your personal settings media/ Default folder for all downloads download_history.csv Keeps a record of every video/audio you’ve downloaded downloader.log Logs errors, messages, and download activity (debugging)

docs.title: No Tracking or Analytics
docs.text: Social Media Downloader does not collect any personal data. All logs, downloads, and settings are stored locally on your own machine. Nothing is sent to external servers.

docs.title: ❓ Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Welcome to the FAQ section for Social Media Downloader! This page addresses the most common questions to help you use the tool effectively and confidently.

docs.title: What is Social Media Downloader
docs.text: Social Media Downloader is a lightweight, open-source command-line tool that allows you to download public videos, reels, and posts from platforms like YouTube, TikTok, Instagram, Facebook, and more. It supports batch downloads and works across different operating systems.

docs.title: Supported Platforms
docs.text:
The tool currently supports content from:

  • YouTube
  • TikTok
  • Instagram
  • Facebook

See the Supported Platforms page for more information.

Tip

Support for additional platforms is planned in future updates.

docs.title: Is It Free to Use?
docs.text: Yes! The tool is completely free and open-source under the MIT License. You are free to view, modify, and distribute it.

docs.title: Private or Password-Protected Content
docs.text:
The tool is designed strictly for downloading public content.

Warning

It does not support downloading private or password-protected media, ensuring user privacy and compliance with platform rules.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
You can install it using pip:

pip install social-media-downloader

Or clone the repository:

git clone https://github.com/nayandas69/Social-Media-Downloader.git
cd Social-Media-Downloader

See the Installation Guide for complete instructions.

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
Run the tool with:

social-media-downloader

Or, from version 1.1.4+, simply use:

smd

Follow the prompts to enter the URL of the content you want to download.

docs.title: Supported File Formats
docs.text:
The tool supports formats like:

  • MP4 (video)
  • MP3 (audio)
  • IMG (Only Instagram)

You’ll be able to choose your preferred format during download.

docs.title: Batch Downloads
docs.text:
You can download multiple videos at once — especially for Instagram.

Danger

Batch downloading currently supports Instagram only.

docs.title: Is There a GUI?
docs.text:
Not yet. The tool is currently CLI-based.

Tip

A graphical user interface (GUI) may be introduced in a future release.

docs.title: How to Update
docs.text:
If installed via pip, update it using:

pip install --upgrade social-media-downloader

For other methods, see the Installation Guide.

docs.title: Fixing "ModuleNotFoundError" with pyfiglet
docs.text:
This occurs when PyInstaller doesn’t bundle font files. Here's how to fix it:

  1. Generate a spec file:
pyi-makespec --onefile smd/downloader.py
  1. Edit the .spec file to include:
from PyInstaller.utils.hooks import collect_data_files
datas = collect_data_files("pyfiglet")
  1. Rebuild:

docs.text: Currently, only standard posts and videos are supported. Stories and live videos are not available.

docs.title: Download Location
docs.text:
By default, all content is saved to a folder named media in your current directory.

You can customize this via config.json.

docs.title: About config.json
docs.text:
This file is created the first time you run the tool and stores default settings like:

{
  "default_format": "show_all",
  "download_directory": "media",
  "history_file": "download_history.csv",
  "mp3_quality": "192"
}

Tip

You can manually edit this file to change download paths or audio quality.

Danger

A new config.json, media folder, and download_history.csv will be created if you run the tool from a different directory.

docs.title: Changing MP3 Quality
docs.text:
Edit the "mp3_quality" field in config.json:

"mp3_quality": "320"

Tip

Make sure ffmpeg is installed for audio conversions.

docs.text: The download_history.csv file logs all your downloads with timestamps, formats, and URLs — useful for tracking.

docs.title: Log File

docs.text:

  • Use telemetry
  • Collect any personal data

docs.text: You can use the tool offline after installation, but downloads still require an internet connection.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Welcome to the installation guide for Social Media Downloader — a lightweight, open-source CLI tool for downloading public videos from platforms like YouTube, TikTok, Instagram, and more.

This page walks you through installing the tool via pip, source code, standalone .exe, .deb package, or binary .tar.gz.

Question

Need help using the tool after installation? Check out the Usage Guide for step-by-step instructions and examples.

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
If you'd like to run the tool from source or contribute to development:

git clone https://github.com/nayandas69/Social-Media-Downloader.git
cd Social-Media-Downloader

docs.title: Set Up a Python Environment
docs.text: We recommend using Python 3.10+ and creating a virtual environment to manage dependencies cleanly.

docs.title: On Windows
docs.text:
python -m venv venv
venv\Scripts\activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: On Linux
docs.text:
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip3 install -r requirements.txt

Quote

Running from source requires installing dependencies listed in requirements.txt.

docs.title: Install FFmpeg (Required)
docs.text:
Important

ffmpeg is essential for handling video/audio formats. The downloader will not work without it.

docs.title: On Windows
docs.text:
1. Visit ffmpeg.org and download the latest static build.
  2. Extract the archive.
  3. Add the bin directory to your system PATH.

docs.title: On Linux
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install ffmpeg

To verify:

ffmpeg -version

If you see version details, you're good to go!

docs.title: Install via pip
docs.text:
Installing via pip is the quickest and most recommended method.

pip install social-media-downloader

Once installed, you can run the downloader using:

social-media-downloader

Or, if you're using version 1.1.4 or newer:

smd

Warning

The smd shortcut is only available in versions v1.1.4 and above.

docs.title: Install on Windows via .exe
docs.text:
Info

No Python required — just download and run!

  1. Visit the Releases page.
  2. Download the latest .exe file.
  3. Double-click to launch the terminal interface.

docs.title: Install on Linux via .deb
docs.text:
For Debian/Ubuntu-based distributions:

  1. Download the .deb package from the Releases.
  2. Install it using:
sudo dpkg -i social-media-downloader_VERSION_amd64.deb
sudo apt-get install -f

Once installed, run the tool with:

smd

Danger

You may need to adjust your $PATH or shell environment for the CLI shortcut.

docs.title: Install on Linux via .tar.gz Binary
docs.text:
If you're using a non-Debian Linux distribution or prefer a portable install:

  1. Download the .tar.gz binary from the Releases.
  2. Extract it and make it executable:
tar -xvf smd-linux.tar.gz
chmod +x smd
./smd

docs.text:

Warning

Ensure ffmpeg is installed on your system or the tool will not function.

docs.title: 🛠️ Troubleshooting
docs.text: Ran into a hiccup while building or running Social Media Downloader? No worries — here’s how to fix the most common issue related to PyFiglet fonts when using PyInstaller.

docs.title: Problem: Missing PyFiglet Fonts
docs.text:
If you see an error like this when you run the executable:

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pyfiglet.fonts'

Note

This happens because PyInstaller doesn't automatically bundle the font files that pyfiglet uses internally.

Without these fonts, your fancy ASCII banners won’t show up, and the script will crash on launch. Let’s fix that.

docs.title: Solution: Manually Include the Font Data
Step 1: Generate a .spec File
docs.text:
Run this command to generate a basic .spec file for your project:

pyi-makespec --onefile --icon=assets/logo.ico smd/downloader.py

This will create a file called downloader.spec.

docs.title: Step 2: Edit the Spec File
docs.text:
Open downloader.spec in your code editor and replace its content with the following:

# -*- mode: python ; coding: utf-8 -*-

from PyInstaller.utils.hooks import collect_data_files

datas = collect_data_files("pyfiglet")

a = Analysis(
    ['smd/downloader.py'],
    pathex=[],
    binaries=[],
    datas=datas,
    hiddenimports=[],
    hookspath=[],
    hooksconfig={},
    runtime_hooks=[],
    excludes=[],
    noarchive=False,
    optimize=0,
)

pyz = PYZ(a.pure)

exe = EXE(
    pyz,
    a.scripts,
    a.binaries,
    a.datas,
    [],
    name='downloader',
    debug=False,
    bootloader_ignore_signals=False,
    strip=False,
    upx=True,
    upx_exclude=[],
    runtime_tmpdir=None,
    console=True,
    disable_windowed_traceback=False,
    argv_emulation=False,
    target_arch=None,
    codesign_identity=None,
    entitlements_file=None,
    icon='assets/logo.ico',
)

What this does:

  • It tells PyInstaller to explicitly include all the font data from pyfiglet, so your executable has everything it needs to render text art properly.

docs.title: Step 3: Rebuild Using the .spec File
docs.text:
Now that your spec file is set up, rebuild the project using:

pyinstaller downloader.spec

This will package the fonts correctly and produce a working binary inside the dist/ folder.

docs.title: Final Result
docs.text:
After building, check inside the dist/ directory. You should now have a fully working standalone executable with no missing font errors — and your sweet ASCII art banners will look just the way they should.

Tip

Want more help customizing your build? Head over to the Build Instructions for extra tips on icons, silent mode, and cleanup options.

Got another error or issue? Feel free to open an issue on GitHub — we’re here to help.

docs.title: 📦 Using `social-media-downloader` in Your Python Project
docs.text: Welcome to the guide on how to use the Social Media Downloader (SMD) Python package in your own projects or as a standalone CLI tool. This page covers installation, importing functions, using the CLI, and working examples.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To get started, install the package from PyPI:

pip install social-media-downloader
````

!!! note
   Requires **Python 3.10+**. Ensure your environment uses a compatible version.


## Importing SMD in Your Python Code

Once installed, you can import and use all major functions directly:

```python
from smd import (
    download_youtube_or_tiktok_video,
    download_instagram_post,
    extract_instagram_video_mp3,
    batch_download_from_file,
    check_for_updates,
    show_help,
)

docs.title: Example: Download a YouTube Video
docs.text:
from smd import download_youtube_or_tiktok_video

video_url = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ"
download_youtube_or_tiktok_video(video_url)

docs.title: Example: Download an Instagram Post
docs.text:
from smd import download_instagram_post

post_url = "https://www.instagram.com/p/CxA-Example/"
download_instagram_post(post_url)

docs.title: Example: Batch Download from File
docs.text:
from smd import batch_download_from_file

batch_download_from_file("batch_links.txt")

Tip

The batch_links.txt file should contain one Instagram post URL per line.

docs.title: Use in Tests and Dev Projects
docs.text:
You can install with development tools using:

pip install 'social-media-downloader[dev]'

This will install additional tools like pytest, flake8, and black.

docs.title: Using SMD as a CLI Tool
docs.text:
After installation, you can run it from your terminal:

smd

or

social-media-downloader

This launches the interactive menu where you can select to download from YouTube, Instagram, check for updates, or view help.

docs.title: Running as a Python Module
docs.text:
Alternatively, you can launch it like this:

python -m smd

Tip

This is helpful when running from a virtual environment or inside scripts.

docs.title: Full API Reference
docs.text:
Here's a quick reference of available methods:

Function Description download_youtube_or_tiktok_video(url) Downloads video from supported platforms download_instagram_post(url) Downloads single Instagram post extract_instagram_video_mp3(url) Extracts MP3 from an Instagram video batch_download_from_file(file_path) Batch downloads from a file check_for_updates() Checks for the latest version show_help() Displays the CLI help menu load_config() Loads or resets the configuration file check_internet_connection() Checks if internet is available is_valid_platform_url(url, allowed_domains) Validates URL against supported platforms get_unique_filename(filename) Ensures downloaded file doesn't overwrite existing ones log_download(url, status) Logs download attempts to history
